metadata.titleEn: Geochronological and geochemical data of igneous rocks and detrital zircons around Darucuo, central Tibet
metadata.description: The dataset includes whole-rock major and trace elemental data, whole-rock Sr-Nd isotopic data, zircon U-Pb ages and Hf-O isotopic data of volcanic and granitic rocks, and U-Pb age of detrital zircons from sandstones. The samples were collected from the Darucuo area in central Tibet, including granodiorite, monzonite, syenite, andesite, dacite, rhyolite, sandstone, and slate. The whole-rock major elements were analyzed by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) on fused glass disks and trace elements were measured using an Agilent Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry system. The zircon U-Pb ages and Hf isotopes are obtained by laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer. The whole-rock Sr-Nd isotopes are obtained by analysis of sample separation and multiple collector-inductively coupled plasma–mass spectrometer. The zircon O isotopes are analyzed by secondary ion probe. The data can be used for constraining the age, petrogenesis, and geodynamic settings of magmatism, and provenance analysis of sedimentary rocks.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file: the file name is upb.xls, which represents radioisotope U-Pb data; The file named wrmt.xls represents the major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock; The name of the file is SrNd, which represents the whole rock SR Nd isotopic data; The file name hfo.xls represents zircon HF-O isotope data

literatureList.titleEn: Reconciling Orogenic Drivers for the Evolution of the Bangong‐Nujiang Tethys During Middle‐Late Jurassic
literatureList.referenceEn: Li, S.-M., Wang, Q., Zhu, D.-C., Cawood, P. A., Stern, R. J., Weinberg, R., . . . Mo, X.-X. (2020). Reconciling Orogenic Drivers for the Evolution of the Bangong-Nujiang Tethys During Middle-Late Jurassic. Tectonics, 39(2), e2019TC005951. Retrieved from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1029/2019TC005951. doi:10.1029/2019tc005951

background: Collisional orogenic belts involve an initial accretionary episode of oceanic slab subduction and subsequent continental collision (Cawood et al., 2009; Dewey & Spall, 1975; Murphy & Nance, 1991; Zhu et al., 2019). The magmatic systems that develop on the upper plate during subduction and initial collision record the processes of convergence and orogenesis (Cawood et al., 2009; Stern, 2002; Zhu et al., 2019). The E‐W trending Bangong‐Nujiang suture (BNS; Figures 2a and 2b) in central Tibet separates the Lhasa and Qiangtang Terranes (Kapp & DeCelles, 2019; Zhu et al., 2016). Assembly of the terranes is related to an overall environment of ocean closure and continental collision, but a range of drivers and kinematic scenarios have been invoked for northward subduction based on the rock archive within the BNS and Qiangtang Terrane, including subduction initiation inferred from ophiolites (188–165 Ma; Figure 1a; Tang, Zhai, Hu, Xiao, et al., 2018) and high‐Mg andesites (approximately 163 Ma; Y.C. Zeng, Chen, et al., 2016), Lhasa‐Qiangtang collision on the basis of angular unconformities (approximately 166 Ma; Figure 1d; Ma et al., 2017; Li, Guilmette, et al., 2017; Sun et al., 2018), and ridge subduction from a rock association of adakites and oceanic island basalt (OIB)‐type rocks (160–148 Ma; Figure 1c; S.M. Li, Zhu, et al., 2016; Y.L. Li, He, et al., 2016).
research objective: Our analysis reveals the existence of an overall compressional arc‐trench system divisible from south to north into an accretionary prism, magmatic arc, and retro‐arc sedimentary units, which can be traced over 1,200 km along strike. We propose that this sequence of tectonic events can be integrated into an evolving geodynamic setting involving trench‐parallel ridge collision (170–160 Ma), slab window formation (160–148 Ma), subsequent subduction termination (148–125 Ma), and final Lhasa‐Qiangtang amalgamation (125–105 Ma).
challenges: Determining the divers of orogenesis is crucial for unraveling orogenic evolution, but is often difficult to resolve because of incomplete preservation of the geological record and contrasting interpretations of the record that is preserved.
methods: In this study, we investigated both igneous and sedimentary rocks around the Beila‐Dongqiao section of the suture zone. For the igneous rocks, zircon U‐Pb dating was undertaken on 12 samples, which display oscillatory zoning under cathodoluminescence (CL) imaging. For each sample, 18–30 spots were analyzed and the U‐Pb data were divisible into two age groups (166–163 and 114–112 Ma). Geochemical compositions and zircon Hf‐O isotopes of samples from the older group, which is the focus of this study, were also determined. For the nine sandstone samples, both rim and core of detrital zircons as determined by CL imaging were analyzed with 100–140 spots for each sample. All zircon U‐Pb isotopes were analyzed via laser ablation‐inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, following the methods described in Zhang et al. (2019).
findings: A magmatic arc characterized by high‐K calc‐alkaline granitoids and high‐Mg andesites, dacites, and rhyolites was active at 166–160 Ma around Daru Tso in the eastern Bangong‐Nujiang suture. The Beila‐Nagqu mélange belt and the Daoban formation, to the south and north of the 166–160 Ma arc, formed contemporaneously and were sourced from the arc. Our new data in the eastern segment, along with existing data in the western segment of the suture, imply the development of an overall compressional convergent margin extending over 1,200 km along strike during Middle‐Late Jurassic. A subparallel ridge‐subduction zone interaction event provides a viable model to explain the diverse geological records of the BNS and Qiangtang Terrane and involves subparallel ridge‐trench collision (170–160 Ma), slab window formation (160–148 Ma), and subsequent subduction termination (148–125 Ma).

Verification.Question: Can the geochemical compositions and zircon Hf-O isotopes from samples provide insights into the magmatic arc activities during the Middle-Late Jurassic in this domain?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary method for obtaining zircon U-Pb isotopes laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, cathodoluminescence imaging, or secondary ion mass spectrometry?
Disjunctive.Answer: laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

Disjunctive.Question: For geochemical analyses of whole-rock samples, is X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, or another method predominantly used?
Disjunctive.Answer: X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

Concept Completion.Question: What are the data collection methods used for determining zircon U-Pb ages in igneous and sedimentary rocks?
Concept Completion.Answer: laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

Concept Completion.Question: Where are samples for geochemical and isotopic analyses typically collected in the context of Middle-Late Jurassic magmatic and sedimentary studies?
What challenges are faced in resolving the drivers of orogenesis in collisional orogenic belts?
Concept Completion.Answer: incomplete preservation of the geological record

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to determine zircon U-Pb ages in magmatic rocks from the central Tibet region?
Example.Answer: Zircon U-Pb ages in magmatic rocks are determined using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, where samples are analyzed for their oscillatory zoning under cathodoluminescence imaging, and multiple spots (18–30 per sample) are analyzed for U-Pb data.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered while studying the evolution of collisional orogenic belts using geological data from the Bangong-Nujiang suture zone?
Example.Answer: A challenge in studying the evolution of collisional orogenic belts is determining the drivers of orogenesis, which is difficult due to incomplete preservation of the geological record and contrasting interpretations of the preserved record.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key methods used to obtain zircon U-Pb age data in geochemical research?
Feature Specification.Answer: laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, multiple spots on zircon samples, oscillatory zoning under cathodoluminescence imaging

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main characteristics of geochemical data collected from volcanic and granitic rocks in the context of the central Tibet region?
Feature Specification.Answer: whole-rock major and trace elements, Sr-Nd isotopes, zircon U-Pb ages, Hf-O isotopes

Feature Specification.Question: What are the primary challenges in determining the drivers of orogenesis using geological records in orogenic belts?
Feature Specification.Answer: incomplete preservation of the geological record, contrasting interpretations of the preserved data

Quantification.Question: What is the range of zircon U-Pb age groups determined in the data collection method?
How many spots were analyzed for each sandstone sample in the zircon U-Pb isotope analysis?

Definition.Question: What challenges are commonly encountered in determining the drivers of orogenesis in collisional orogenic belts?
Definition.Answer: Determining the drivers of orogenesis in collisional orogenic belts is challenging due to the incomplete preservation of the geological record and contrasting interpretations of the preserved record.

Definition.Question: What does 'zircon U-Pb isotopes analysis' entail in the context of geological studies?
Definition.Answer: Zircon U-Pb isotope analysis involves measuring the uranium-lead isotopic ratios in zircon crystals to determine their age, providing insights into the timing of geological processes. This technique is often carried out using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry and is used to investigate both igneous and sedimentary rocks.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for zircon U-Pb dating in magmatic systems compare to those used for sedimentary rock analysis in terms of precision and applicability?
Comparison.Answer: The zircon U-Pb dating in magmatic systems involves analyzing 12 samples with oscillatory zoning, using 18-30 spots per sample, which provides precise age divisions. In contrast, sedimentary rock analysis involves analyzing both rim and core of detrital zircons with 100-140 spots per sample, offering a broader applicability in understanding sedimentary provenance.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of zircon U-Pb dating and Hf-O isotopic data provide insights into the geodynamic evolution of orogenic belts?
Interpretation.Answer: By utilizing zircon U-Pb dating and Hf-O isotopic data, researchers can determine the ages and origins of magmatic and sedimentary rocks, which reveal the timing and processes of subduction, collision, and subsequent geological events in orogenic belts. This approach allows for a detailed reconstruction of the tectonic history and the evolution of magmatic arcs, accretionary prisms, and retro-arc sedimentary units.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors influence the selection of data collection methods for analyzing zircon U-Pb ages and isotopic compositions in igneous and sedimentary rocks?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selection of data collection methods for analyzing zircon U-Pb ages and isotopic compositions is influenced by the need for precise age determination and isotopic data, which is critical for understanding the processes of convergence and orogenesis. The use of laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry is chosen for its ability to provide detailed isotopic analysis and age dating necessary for unraveling tectonic events and magmatic activity.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might challenges arise in determining the drivers of orogenesis based on geological records?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in determining the drivers of orogenesis arise due to the often incomplete preservation of geological records and the contrasting interpretations of the preserved records. This complexity is compounded by the diverse geological processes and tectonic events recorded in the rock archives, such as subduction, collision, and magmatic activity, which require comprehensive data collection and analysis methodologies to accurately decipher.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes might lead researchers to focus on specific types of rocks, such as high-Mg andesites and rhyolites, for understanding magmatic arcs in tectonic studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Researchers focus on specific types of rocks, such as high-Mg andesites and rhyolites, because these rocks are indicative of particular magmatic processes and tectonic settings. High-Mg andesites, for instance, are associated with specific tectonic conditions like subduction initiation, and their study helps in reconstructing the history of magmatic arcs and understanding the geodynamic settings during the Middle-Late Jurassic period in regions such as the Bangong-Nujiang suture.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on the understanding of orogenic evolution when using advanced isotopic analysis techniques like laser ablation‐inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon dating?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using advanced isotopic analysis techniques such as laser ablation‐inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon dating can lead to a more precise determination of geological events' timing and origins. This can help unravel the complex history of orogenic evolution by providing detailed age and compositional data, allowing researchers to trace the sequence of tectonic events and understand their geodynamic settings.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind collecting geochemical and isotopic data from volcanic and granitic rocks for understanding the Jurassic magmatic activity in central Tibet?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to define the timing, origin, and formation background of magmatic activities in the region, and to perform provenance analysis of sedimentary rocks.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the geochemical and isotopic analysis of igneous rock samples conducted to understand the magmatic processes in the Bangong-Nujiang suture zone?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The geochemical compositions and zircon Hf-O isotopes of igneous rock samples were determined. These analyses focus on the samples from the older age group to reveal their geochemical characteristics, which involve using techniques like laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for isotopic analysis.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the accurate analysis of zircon U-Pb isotopes in geological samples from Tibet?
Enablement.Answer: The use of laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry has enabled the accurate analysis of zircon U-Pb isotopes in geological samples, allowing researchers to determine precise ages and isotopic compositions.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple geochemical methods enhance the understanding of magmatic processes in the central Tibet region?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of methods such as X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and secondary ion mass spectrometry enhances the understanding of magmatic processes by providing comprehensive geochemical data, including major and trace elements, isotopic compositions, and zircon ages.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for effectively collecting and analyzing Sr-Nd isotopes from whole rock samples in the context of orogenic belts?
Enablement.Answer: Effective collection and analysis of Sr-Nd isotopes from whole rock samples require precise sample separation and purification techniques followed by analysis using multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, ensuring accurate isotopic data reflective of orogenic processes.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in determining the drivers of orogenesis from geological records in the central Tibet region?
Expectation.Answer: Determining the drivers of orogenesis can be difficult due to incomplete preservation of the geological record and contrasting interpretations of the record that is preserved.

Expectation.Question: Why could it be necessary to use multiple techniques, such as laser ablation and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, in analyzing zircon U-Pb isotopes from a geological dataset?
Expectation.Answer: Using multiple techniques, like laser ablation and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, is vital to accurately analyze zircon U-Pb isotopes, ensuring detailed geochronological and isotopic information that supports understanding of tectonic events and magmatic processes.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon U-Pb isotopic analysis in geological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry is highly effective for zircon U-Pb isotopic analysis, as it allows for precise dating of geological events. This method is particularly valuable when investigating both igneous and sedimentary rocks, as demonstrated by the detailed age group analysis achieved in the study of zircon samples.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the challenges in determining the drivers of orogenesis given the incomplete preservation of geological records?
Judgmental.Answer: Determining the drivers of orogenesis is challenging due to the incomplete preservation of geological records, which can lead to contrasting interpretations. However, integrating various data types, such as geochemical compositions and isotopic data, can provide a more comprehensive understanding of the tectonic and magmatic processes involved, despite these challenges.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the methods used for obtaining geochemical compositions and zircon Hf-O isotopes in geological research.
Assertion.Answer: Geochemical compositions and zircon Hf-O isotopes are determined by analyzing igneous rock samples, with zircon U-Pb isotopes specifically being analyzed through laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how sedimentary rock samples contribute to understanding geological processes in suture zones.
Assertion.Answer: Sedimentary rock samples, such as sandstones, are analyzed for detrital zircon U-Pb isotopes, which helps to trace the sources and ages of sediments. This contributes to understanding the deposition environment and processes in suture zones, as demonstrated by the analysis of rim and core detrital zircons in the study.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore different data collection methods used for obtaining zircon U-Pb isotopic data in igneous and sedimentary rocks within the field of geochemistry and geochronology.
Request/Directive.Answer: Zircon U-Pb isotopic data in igneous and sedimentary rocks are obtained using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). This method involves analyzing zircon samples with oscillatory zoning, as observed under cathodoluminescence (CL) imaging, and can distinguish between different age groups by analyzing multiple spots per sample.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the challenges in collecting comprehensive geochemical and isotopic data for sedimentary provenance analysis in orogenic settings.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting comprehensive geochemical and isotopic data for sedimentary provenance analysis include the incomplete preservation of the geological record and contrasting interpretations of the preserved record. Determining the drivers of orogenesis is crucial yet difficult due to these challenges, which can complicate interpretations of orogenic evolution in compressional convergent margins.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential strategies for expanding datasets related to the geochemical characterization of magmatic arcs and their associated sedimentary units.
Request/Directive.Answer: Expanding datasets related to the geochemical characterization of magmatic arcs and associated sedimentary units can involve integrating new zircon U-Pb dating results with geochemical compositions and zircon Hf-O isotopic data. This can be achieved through detailed sampling across different sections of suture zones and applying consistent analytical methods, such as laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry.
